data.text:
The CESTour Conference 2024 at Birla Institute of Management Technology (BIMTECH), focusing on "Navigating the Future of Sustainable Tourism" just concluded. It has been a unique opportunity to listen to the results of many interesting research studies, ranging from the development of indicators for measuring the impacts of climate change on tourism to the comparative analysis of tourism policies at a national and international level. The Conference was also the opportunity to unveil the volume "Sustainable Development in South Asia Tourism", a collaborative effort co-edited with emma zavarrone. The book features contributions from all partner universities of the #CESTour project: FH Joanneum, University of Alicante, IULM University, Birla Institute of Management and Technology, Institute of Public Enterprise, Nirma University, Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India, Tribhuvan University, Global College International, Sabaragamuwa University of Sri Lanka, and Uva Wellassa University. The primary aim of the CESTour project, funded by the European Union through Erasmus+ Capacity Building in Higher Education, is to install centres of excellence for sustainable tourism at seven universities in India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. The collaborative efforts of the partners have resulted in the creation of educational programs, faculty and student enrichment, the development of practical cases, and the establishment of academic and industrial networks to foster the growth of centres of excellence over time. The Work Package led by #IULMUniversity focused in particular on enhancing collaboration between tourism businesses and partner universities, involving students from the centres in case of challenges on sustainable tourism. Led by academic mentors and the business world, students developed and analyzed a series of products, services, and experiences for sustainable tourism in India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka, crafting a compendium of best practices, enriched further by scholarly contributions from Rahul Singh, Friedl Harald A. and Oana M. Driha. #SustainableTourism #CESTourProject #India #Nepal #Srilanka

On September 27th each year World Tourism Day is celebrated globally. It was established by the United Nations World Tourism Organization (UNWTO) to highlight the significance of tourism and its impact on individuals, communities, and nations. To recognize and celebrate the multifaceted importance of tourism - a very special event was organized with G√∂kku≈üaƒüƒ± Beylikd√ºz√º Campus high school students by visiting the most touristic places in Istanbul. In this trip, our students got the chance to learn about history, art, and heritage by reading magnificent works in three major sections in ƒ∞stanbul Archaeological Museum. It has been a great pleasure for us to see our students discovering the richness of the world's cultures once more, which are essential for global harmony in our global society. At the end of the trip our students highlighted the importance of aligning tourism with the SDGs to encourage the development of eco-friendly practices and minimize the negative impacts in popular tourist destinations in Istanbul such as Gulhana Park and Hagia Sophia. As we all know tourism has negative impacts too, and these are often referred to as "damages caused by tourism". We are world changers believe that Sustainable tourism practices and community involvement can help mitigate negative effects and promote tourism that is more environmentally and socially responsible. That is why, our students carried out this a 5-day project to raise awareness regarding higher levels of pollution, including air and water pollution, and improper disposal of waste in peak periods of tourism. Dividing into groups of 3, they first observed the damages caused by tourism by wearing their GLOBAL VISION GLASSES, then presented their worksheets and offered alternative solutions to spread awareness in our school community. I want to extend my thanks to all the faculty of Gokkusagi Schools Beylukduzu Branch, art teachers, and organizers who worked tirelessly to make this opportunity possible. Your guidance and support in making this project has been so meaningful. We all have learned not only about the subject matter but also about the importance of diligence, creativity, perseverance and overall approach to learning and problem-solving. #sdggoals #globalschools #climatechange #sdg13 #sustainableliving #worldchangers #globalgoalsproject #tourism #pollution

The next 10 years are looking to be bright for Geelong and The Bellarine region! With clear strategic directions and targeted investment, the region could attract 14 million annual visits by 2032. Our 10-year tourism strategy for Tourism Greater Geelong & The Bellarine sets out a road-map of how this can be achieved through protecting iconic landscapes, celebrating cultural heritage, creating new experiences, and driving greater diversity of visitor markets that multiply benefits throughout the region. The Sustainable Destination Master Plan launched this week, and we are excited to see the impact it will have on shaping visitor trends across the Geelong region. In true multi-disciplinary fashion, experts from our Economics & Property, Planning, Spatial, and Creative teams all collaborated on this project to deliver an ambitious and innovative road-map. With a focus on improvements that will create long-lasting changes to visitors‚Äô impressions of Geelong and The Bellarine, we are confident that the Plan can ‚Äì and will ‚Äì deliver a sustainable and thriving tourism region, making Geelong and the Bellarine the place to do, not simply see!
